Dear Brandon Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract. Review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with
any questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(v) Peer-on-peer discipline.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In October 2022, two youth engaged in a physical altercation at
the facility. Two staff members instructed two other youth to break
up the fight rather than attempt to do so themselves. A supervisor
responded and broke it up. One of the youth that attempted to
intervene was assaulted in the process.
Investigation On 01/27/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Youth A
confirmed she currently resides in Unit 2 and has been at the
facility for four months. Youth A reported that all the youth had
went out to an outing to Golden Coral and when they returned
there was a mix up with laundry that led to an altercation between
her and Youth B. Youth A reported that Youth B was upset and
continued to “act up”. Youth A recalled that staff called for “peer
support”. Youth A defined “peer support” as defending yourself
and being aware of everything around you. Youth A admitted that
she got “fed up” with the actions of Youth B and “swung” on her
and they started to fight. Youth A reported that a staff broke up
the fight but was unable to recall who the staff was. Youth A
denied that any other youth assisted in breaking up the fight.
Youth A denied that staff instructed youth to break up the fight.
Youth A later confirmed that there are times when youth break up
fights. She reported that there was another fight, but that she did
not want to talk about it because it is a trigger for her. Youth A
indicated that youth in the unit used to have positions assigned by
staff. The positions included Unit Manager, School Manager, Line
Manager, Meal Manager and Victors Club. Youth A went on to
indicate that if youth held any of these positions, then youth
helped to break up the fights. She clarified that staff also helped.
Youth A denied that anyone has gotten hurt during the fights. She
reported again that staff always help to break up the fights and
2

denied that any staff or managers told youth to break up fights.
Youth A reported that she does it because youth should help, and
no one should get hurt. On 02/28/2023 a second in-person
interview was held with Youth A at Vassar House. The DHHS
specialist was present also. A second interview was completed
with the youth to obtain information regarding alleged injuries she
obtained as a result of an altercation with Youth B. She confirmed
that she had some scratches on her neck after the fight and stated
that she saw the nurse but does not remember the name of the
nurse. She recalled that she also had some back pain but denied
headaches or anything else. Youth A reported that she told a staff
but does not recall the name. Youth A then asked to go back to
her unit as she reported being annoyed by having to meet with
licensing and DHHS. She further stated that the meeting was
triggering her. Youth A reported that she recalled staff trying to
break up the fight. She then reiterated that she did not want to
talk about this topic or with myself and the DHHS specialist.
On 01/27/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the complaint.
No additional information was provided.
On 01/27/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth B at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was present for the
interview. Youth B confirmed that she previously resided in Unit 2,
but now resides in Unit 4. Youth B described two fights that she
was involved in with Youth A. She reported that some youth came
and tried to hold them back and says that staff just stood by and
did not do anything. Youth B reported Staff 1 and Staff 5 were
present and told youth to break up the fight. Youth B stated that
youth care supervisors came to assist as she thinks they were
contacted by Staff 1 and Staff 5. She reported that Youth C was
one of the youths involved and she got some scratches from
helping out. Youth B confirmed she got a black eye from the fight
and Youth A had no injuries. Youth B reported there was a
second fight between her, and Youth A and she confirmed that
staff intervened, and no youth were involved. Youth B later
denied that youth are asked to help when peers are fighting but
thinks they do it to show leadership. Youth B confirmed that staff
would sometimes say “peer support” but denied knowing what the
statement meant. Youth B reported that she never saw “peer
support” happen but stated that Staff 8 would say you are not
going to like it.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth C at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was present for the
interview. Youth C confirmed that she was in a unit with Youth A.
3

Youth C confirmed that she restrained Youth B about one week
ago. She reported that Youth A was trying to harm herself and
Staff 3 and Staff 4 were present and did not intervene. She
recalled that Staff 4 said that they couldn’t touch Youth A. Youth
C reported that Youth A usually responds to Youth C, so that is
why she tried to intervene. She described the behaviors that
Youth A was engaging in as banging her head, licking the socket,
tying things around her neck, biting herself and ripping her shirt.
On 02/01/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 1 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
confirmed that she has been working with the agency for 8 years
and is a youth specialist. Staff 1 confirmed that she was working
when a fight occurred on the unit between Youth A and Youth B.
She reported that the two were separated by staff. Staff 1 also
indicated that she is able to give “verbal” commands and youth will
listen. She denied that other youth got involved in the altercation
on that day. Staff 1 reported that she let the supervisor “deal with”
Youth B to calm her down. She does not recall if Youth A or
Youth B got injured. Staff 1 reported that she does not think that
youth get involved and denied seeing Youth C intervene. She
denied personally allowing or encouraging other youth to get
involved but recalled youth calling “group secure” back when they
had “positions”. Staff 1 denied any youth became involved in the
fight between Youth A and Youth B on this day. She denied
instructing youth to break up the fight and denied hearing any
other staff instruct youth to break up the fight. She further denied
using the verbiage “peer support”. She reported that she has
heard other staff use it and understands that it means peer to peer
encouragement/redirection when youth are off task.
On 03/06/23 an phone interview of Staff 5 occurred. The DHHS
specialist also participated. Staff 5 denied asking youth to break
up fights between peers but confirmed seeing youth intervene on
their own. Staff 5 confirmed that she would allow youth to
intervene if they were not making it worse. She gave examples of
intervening to be “pulling youth back by their arm and talking them
down”. She further indicated that she would allow it based on the
situation and who the youth were. She denied seeing Staff 1
instruct youth to break up fights. Staff 5 stated that when youth
were intervening (which she described as helping out), the staff
would be providing “back up” to the youth.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2
reported that she did not have information regarding potential
4

restraints of Youth A. Staff 2 reported that she would be surprised
to hear youth are reporting that they have engaged in restraints.
Staff 2 denied that she has seen youth restrain other youth and
denied that she has knowledge of staff failing to intervene when
youth are involved in an altercation.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 4 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 4
stated that she does not like doing restraints but will do them if
necessary. She further stated that she recalled an incident
involving Youth A back in October 2022. She confirmed that she
witnessed Youth C and Youth E engaging with Youth A but was
unsure if they were “playing” or not. She denied that staff failed to
intervene. She specifically indicated that she was not clear if the
youth were just playing with each other and thus did not required
intervention. Staff 4 reported that the youth try to act as managers
but are redirected by staff consistently. She reported that the
youth are reminded that they cannot touch each other and to
respect boundaries of each other.
On 03/06/2023 an telephone interview was held with Staff 7. The
DHHS specialist also participated. Staff 7 denied that it is
common practice for staff to allow youth to intervene. She
reported that policy specifically documents that this is not allowed,
and that youth should not intervene. Staff 7 denied being aware
of Staff 1 or Staff 5 allowing youth to intervene.
Analysis After the conclusion of the investigation there was not sufficient
evidence to support that staff were “instructing” youth to break up
fights. All youth and staff interviewed denied that staff direct youth
to physically intervene with other youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Additional findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff are present and aware when fighting occurs amongst peers
and staff fail to intervene.
5

Investigation On 01/27/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth B at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Youth B
described two fights that she was involved in with Youth A. She
reported that some youth came and tried to hold them back and
reported staff just stood by and did not intervene.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth C at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was present for the
interview. Youth C confirmed that she was in a unit with Youth A
back in October. She reported that Youth A was trying to harm
herself and Staff 3 and Staff 4 were present and did not intervene.
She recalled that Staff 4 told them that they couldn’t touch Youth
A, but that she did not make any additional attempts to stop her
from holding her down to stop her from hurting herself. Youth C
reported that Youth A usually responds to her, so that is why she
tried to intervene. She described the behaviors that Youth A was
engaging in as banging her head, licking the socket, tying things
around her neck, biting herself and ripping her shirt.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 3 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was present also. She
reported she is a four-year employee on second shift. Staff 3
denied seeing youth restrain other youth at the facility. She
reported that “kids do what they want around here”. She reported
that staff would redirect and then call the supervisor. She recalled
that Youth D was recently out of control in the unit. She confirmed
that Youth C and Youth E were trying to calm Youth D down and
tried to restrain her. When asked what staff was doing when
youth are intervening or attempting restraints, Staff 3 advised that
the staff would be intervening and breaking up fights of the youth.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 4 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 4
stated that she recalled an incident involving Youth A back in
October 2022. She confirmed that she witnessed Youth C and
Youth E engaging with Youth A but was unsure if they were
“playing” or not. She denied that staff failed to intervene. She
specifically indicated that she was not clear if the youth were just
playing with each other and thus did not require intervention.
Staff 4 did report that the youth try to act as managers but are
redirected by staff consistently. She reported that the youth are
reminded that they cannot touch each other and to respect
boundaries of each other.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2
6

reported that staff will redirect youth and encourage them not to
get involved with attempts to restrain other youth. She denied
seeing any youth try to restrain any other youth and reported that
staff always intervenes and attempts to redirect negative behavior
by the youth.
On 03/06/23 an phone interview of Staff 5 occurred. The DHHS
specialist also participated. Staff 5 denied asking youth to break
up fights between peers but confirmed seeing youth intervene on
their own. Staff 5 confirmed that she would allow youth to
intervene if they were not making it worse. She gave examples of
intervening to be “pulling youth back by their arm and talking them
down”. She further indicated that she would allow it based on the
situation and who the youth were. She denied seeing Staff 1
instruct youth to break up fights. Staff 5 stated that when youth
were intervening (which she described as helping out), the staff
would be providing “back up” to the youth.
On 03/17/2023 a DHHS closing case conference was held. The
DHHS specialist advised that she would have findings of improper
supervisor resulting in some confirmed cases.
Analysis After the conclusion of the investigation there was sufficient
evidence to support that staff were aware of youth intervening with
other youth and failed to intervene and ensure safety of all youth.
Staff 5 reported she allows youth to intervene, and staff act as
“back up”, Staff 4 stated she just thought the youth were “playing”
and didn’t intervene. Both Youth B and Youth C indicated staff
failed to intervene.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0137003; CAP approved 03/14/2023
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the that
the current license status be continued.
